title: 113_hr5476
content:
The "Cabin Fee Act of 2014" is also known as the Cabin User Fees Act. The Secretary of Agriculture will establish a fee for special use permits on National Forest System land for recreational residence purposes. An interim fee will be assessed until the current appraisal cycle is completed, with the fee being the lesser of the amount determined under the Cabin User Fee Fairness Act of 2000 or $5,600. The Secretary will establish a fee for special use permits on National Forest System land for recreational residences, with the fee being the lesser of 25 percent of the previous year's fee or $5,600. The current appraisal cycle must be completed within one year, using approved appraisals to determine lot values. The Secretary will adjust the value of each appraised lot with a recreational residence to reflect changes in value. An annual fee will be assessed based on the adjusted lot values. The annual fee for recreational residences on National Forest System land will be determined by a tiered fee structure. The fee for recreational residences on National Forest System land is determined by a tiered fee structure, with fees ranging from $650 to $4,650 based on different tiers representing varying percentages of permits nationally. Tier 9 - 3% - $4,650
Tier 10 - 3% - $5,150
Tier 11 - 1% - $5,650. The Secretary adjusts annual fees based on changes in the Implicit Price Deflator for the Gross Domestic Product. Criteria are established for temporarily suspending or reducing fees if access or occupancy of the recreational residence is restricted. Owners have the right to appeal administrative decisions. The Secretary adjusts annual fees based on economic indicators. Owners have the right to appeal fee determinations. Every 10 years, a report is submitted to review fee fairness. The Secretary adjusts annual fees based on economic indicators and owners can appeal fee determinations. A report is submitted every 10 years to review fee fairness. The fee system may be modified based on the Secretary's recommendations, with no requirement for appraisals. The Secretary establishes a $1,200 fee for transferring recreational residence permits due to ownership changes, with annual adjustments based on economic indicators. The Act does not limit US rights to land in the National Forest System, and in Alaska, fees must align with existing laws. SEC. 5. RETENTION OF FEES. The Secretary can keep and use fees collected under this Act for administering recreation programs on National Forest System land. SEC. 6. REPEAL OF CABIN USER FEE FAIRNESS ACT OF 2000. The Cabin User Fee Fairness Act of 2000 is repealed upon the assessment of annual permit fees.
